Also, it's not a bug in pytorch, but rather a way that variable binding works in python (i.e. variables are shadowed at the beginning of a function, not when they're actually defined inside it). When you do a local import you're actually creating a local variable named torch, and this shadows the definition of the global one. This snippet will also raise an error:

x = 1
def q():
    print(x)
    x = 4
q()

body:
Also, it's not a bug in pytorch, but rather a way that variable binding works in python (i.e. variables are shadowed at the beginning of a function, not when they're actually defined inside it). When you do a local import you're actually creating a local variable named `torch`, and this shadows the definition of the global one. This snippet will also raise an error:

```python
x = 1
def q():
    print(x)
    x = 4
q()
```
